thread.title: In Peoria, Caterpillar's move feels like 'kick in the gut'
thread.title_full: In Peoria, Caterpillar's move feels like 'kick in the gut'

author: Greg Trotter
title: In Peoria, Caterpillar's move feels like 'kick in the gut'
text:
In Peoria, Caterpillar's move feels like 'kick in the gut' Peoria resident discusses move of Caterpillar headquarters to Chicago area 
Peoria resident and worker Ryan Murphy discusses Caterpillar's plan to move its headquarters out of Peoria to the Chicago area on Jan. 31, 2017. (John J. Kim, Chicago Tribune) 
Peoria resident and worker Ryan Murphy discusses Caterpillar's plan to move its headquarters out of Peoria to the Chicago area on Jan. 31, 2017. (John J. Kim, Chicago Tribune) Greg Trotter Peoria mayor on losing Caterpillar HQ 
Peoria Mayor Jim Ardis on losing the global headquarters of Caterpillar to the Chicago area. Jan. 31, 2017 (Greg Trotter / Chicago Tribune) 
Peoria Mayor Jim Ardis on losing the global headquarters of Caterpillar to the Chicago area. Jan. 31, 2017 (Greg Trotter / Chicago Tribune) See more videos 
The imprint of Caterpillar on Peoria seems nearly ubiquitous when driving in on Interstate 74. Motorists can stop in at the 50,000-square-foot Caterpillar Visitor Center, which houses a company museum. The minor-league Peoria Chiefs play baseball at Dozer Park, named after Caterpillar bulldozers. 
What does Caterpillar mean to Peoria? 
"There's a term for it, that if you work for Caterpillar, you bleed yellow," said Ryan Murphy, 46, a former Caterpillar employee who now runs a downtown bar. "So many people's whole families work for Caterpillar." 
And though Murphy said the move would hurt downtown business, he believed the town's economy would survive the loss. 
"It's just one of those bumps in the road where you see the pothole coming and ... and you hope you don't have a flat tire," Murphy said. 
When Paul Berres, 58, heard the news, he immediately called his father, a former Caterpillar employee now living in Florida. Beyond the jobs, the company also has provided a trickle-down benefit to other businesses, as well as community philanthropy, said Berres, co-owner of Born Paint Co.
